posts.name: Marshall Tappen
posts.cooked:
Hello,

We are trying to control a CANSparkMax PID Loop with the Thru-Bore encoder working as an absolute encoder. We can read the encoder, but the motor controller PID Loop doesn’t seem to be driving the motor.  Is it possible to use the absolute encoder to directly drive the onboard PID Loop or do we need to initialize the NEO encoder from the absolute encoder and use the NEO for the PID Loop?

Thanks!

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: I don’t see any reason u can’t use the through bore. That’s what we are doing. Are u connecting the encoder to the sparkmax or the Rio? What’s does ur code look like?

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
This does work.  There are a couple of things you should check:

You should have the through-bore encoder plugged into the Spark Max using this , or a custom wiring solution.  It sounds like you’ve done that already because you can read the encoder.

Make sure you have the latest firmware installed on the Spark Max, as older firmwares didn’t support this.  Again, it sounds like you’ve done that already because you can read the encoder.

Make sure you are using these methods to tell the PID controller to use the absolute encoder as the input device:

https://codedocs.revrobotics.com/java/com/revrobotics/cansparkmax#getPIDController()

https://codedocs.revrobotics.com/java/com/revrobotics/sparkmaxpidcontroller#setFeedbackDevice(com.revrobotics.MotorFeedbackSensor)

https://codedocs.revrobotics.com/java/com/revrobotics/cansparkmax#getAbsoluteEncoder(com.revrobotics.SparkMaxAbsoluteEncoder.Type)

Your code should look something like:

mySparkMax.getPIDController().setFeedbackDevice(mySparkMax.getAbsoluteEncoder( SparkMaxAbsoluteEncoder.Type.kDutyCycle));

link_counts.title: Alternate Encoder Adapter - 2 Pack - REV Robotics

posts.name: Marshall Tappen
posts.cooked: Thanks for the confirmation!  I think we narrowed it to an inexplicable SparkMax issue.  SparkMax A and SparkMax B are both reset to factory settings.  PID Control and motor.set() work great on SparkMax A, so we are confident in our code.  On SparkMax B, motor.set() works, but the PID code produces no response on the motor, even using the factory settings.

posts.name: JCharlton
posts.cooked: I’m no expert on the new motor controllers, but is it possible that you haven’t set a Kp value on SparkMax B?

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: It’s my understanding that you should be using the getAlternateEncoder as seen in the following example?

posts.name: Marshall Tappen
posts.cooked: Thanks!  Setting the feedback controller finally seemed to work for us, but all of the above advice is correct.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: How did u end up getting the absolute encoders working with the sparkmax?

posts.name: Marshall Tappen
posts.cooked: Use the getAbsoluteEncoder and the SetFeedbackDevice calls and it worked great. As a side note, do not use alternate encoder mode, we thought that sounded right , but it will disable the absolute encoder.

posts.name: roborb
posts.cooked: Hi, when using the Throughbore Encoder as an Absolute Encoder, what values should be used in the setReference() call? As per the man page the value should be -1 and +1 for DutyCycle control mode.  How to convert the Arm degrees to a value in [-1, 1] range?

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
The absolute encoder is preset to reference a little indentation/line that’s molded into the encoder.  If you need to have the zero position be somewhere else, it’s easiest to just adjust the raw position reading to compensate for this.  This only works when running PID on the roboRIO, but we like this arrangement, particularly for things like arms (more complicated feedforward due to gravity, soft limits that kick in gradually, avoids any potential issue with controller resets, etc.).

In C++, the units library takes care of this type of conversion, and there’s a turn_t, as well as a degree_t type.  With Java, going from +/-180 degrees to +/-1 is just a matter of dividing by 180.0.  Be careful that the input really is limited to this range, particularly if you add/subtract something from it in computing the reference value.

posts.name: roborb
posts.cooked: Thank you for the detailed explanation!  I didn’t notice the notch on the case for the zero position.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: You can adjust the absolute encoder zero point with encoder.SetZeroOffset(offset);
